awd_titl_txt: Lithographic Patterning of Co-Dispersed Nanomaterials for Device Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Hybrid inorganic nanoparticle-polymer matrix composite materials that are fabricated into nanoscale pattern arrays on a flexible or rigid substrate offer a wide range of novel optical and electronic properties. New devices can be created from intermediate scale features where transitional properties between molecular and bulk behaviors can be accessed and controlled. To realize nanomanufacturing of such hybrid materials, low-cost, flexible, simple, and scalable methods need to be developed to efficiently organize inorganic and organic species into a large number of features with distinct functions. Self-assembly is prone to defect formation and probe- and e-beam-based lithography techniques are often too slow for mass production. This award investigates a broadly applicable nanoimprint lithography process for patterning nanoparticle-polymer hybrid composite materials and to use them to manufacture nano-scale optical and electronic devices. This is accomplished by using nanoparticles dispersed in organic solvents that can fill nanoimprinted polymer molds quickly and then be consolidated to form patterned features with high nanoparticle loadings. The project provides training to both graduate and undergraduate students. Several outreach activities on the Virginia Tech campus and summer camps at Science Museum of Western Virginia are planned to increase the enrollment of females and minorities in engineering.

Nanoimprint lithography can transfer nanoscale patterns with high fidelity and repeatability in large scales. However, most of the research has been focused on pure polymeric material systems. This project explores nanoimprint lithography for nanoparticle-polymer hybrid patterning by addressing the key scientific challenges of nanoparticle and polymer (monomer) co-dispersion in organic solvents and patterning the nanoparticle and polymer co-suspensions into nano-scale features using the evaporative nature of dispersing solvents and the polymer chain transition from dispersed and soluble state to solid state. The research work fully explores different methods of nanoparticle dispersion in organic solvents in the presence of polymeric chains. The understanding of nanoparticle-polymer co-dispersion and organic solvent evaporation during lithographic molding promises to push the boundaries of novel hybrid pattern formation. In contrast to traditional nanoimprint lithography, which uses polymer materials only, a new class of hybrid materials with intricate architectures and novel functionalities is expected. The hybrid patterns can offer a wide range of feature arrangements for direct device uses. This holds great scientific and application potentials by combining the knowledge at the boundaries of the particle-solvent-polymer and liquid-solid domains.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

This project explores nanoimprint lithography for nanoparticle-polymer hybrid patterning by addressing the key scientific challenges of nanoparticle and polymer (monomer) co-dispersion in organic solvents and patterning nanoparticle and polymer co-suspensions into nano-scale features using the evaporative nature of dispersing solvents and the polymer chain transition from the dispersed and soluble state to the solid state. We have studied different methods of nanoparticle dispersion in organic solvents in the presence of polymeric chains. In contrast to traditional nanoimprint lithography, which uses polymer materials only, a new class of hybrid materials with intricate architectures and novel functionalities have been made. The hybrid patterns offere a wide range of feature arrangements for direct device uses. This holds great scientific and application potentials by combining the knowledge at the boundaries of the particle-solvent-polymer and liquid-solid domains.

Intellectual merit:

Au nanoparticles (NPs) of 5 nm in size have been introduced into polystyrene thin films. The effect of different concentrations of Au NPs dispersed in the film has been analyzed to understand the variation in memory characteristics and flexibility of the films. The films are flexible for making flexible electronic devices. These properties and effects are key in developing memory window and maintaining flexibility in organic thin film transistor devices. Photo-induced healing efficiency of the gold (Au) nanoparticle (NP)-polystyrene (PS) systems with Au NP concentrations up to 1 wt% has been examined. Furthermore, the effects of the Au NP concentration, agglomeration, and interparticle distance on the photothermal heating are analyzed using two different scale finite element models.

ZnO nanoparticle-polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) hybrid films are made using a solvent-assisted method. The effects of the ZnO content on microstructures, mechanical properties, and optical properties are investigated. The effect of long-term UV irradiation has also been performed to evaluate the effect of ZnO addition on the degradation of the hybrids. An effective submicron patterning process of ZnO quantum dot/poly(methyl methacrylate) hybrids has been developed with a solvent-assisted lithographic technique. Feature sizes down to 250 nm have been achieved with a ZnO content up to 50 vol %, about 10 times higher than the literature-reported inorganic contents. With higher ZnO contents, particles show a tendency to aggregate, and the samples have less flexibility as demonstrated by larger bending radii before failure. The higher ZnO content samples also produce stronger photoluminescence responses. This family of materials has a great potential to be used in flexible optical devices.

The agglomeration processes of ZnO nanoparticle and poly(methyl methacrylate) polymer cosuspensions have been studied through a constant number Monte Carlo simulation. A modified Derjaguin-Landau-Verwey-Overbeek theory is used to describe the particle-particle interactions that lead to agglomeration. We have also used the Monte Carlo simulation method to evaluate the agglomeration behaviors of different ZnO nanoparticle and polymethacrylate hybrid suspensions in an organic solvent. Interaction energies are primarily from the steric layer on the particle surfaces. The effects of nanoparticle size, steric layer thickness, particle content, and total solids loading are evaluated based on the average agglomerate size and agglomeration rate. Smaller particle, thicker steric layer, lower particle content, and higher solids loading are desirable factors to stabilize a suspension. The average agglomerate size and number are measured as a function of suspension resting time, particle to polymer volume ratio, polymer chain length, and total solids loading. This work provides important guidance for co?dispersing nanoparticles and dissolved polymer chains in organic solvents.

Combining quantum dots with a polymer matrix is a potential way to endow flexible polymer material with novel functionalities. We have used polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) as a stamp for sub-500 nm patterning through a solvent-assisted imprint method. ZnO nanoparticles of 5 nm size has been synthesized and dispersed homogeneously in a poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) matrix. Features as small as 250 nm have been generated and quantitatively evaluated.

 

Broader impacts:

Outreach to K-12 female and minority students on the Virginia Tech campus (C-Tech2, Women's preview weekend, Hypatia) as well as to Western Virginia Science Museum has been accomplished. A comprehensive diversity program encompassing undergraduate students, graduate students, faculty, and staff has been made possible in the MSE program of Virginia Tech. The PIs have also been involved in the college and university level diversity efforts by promoting diversity efforts among undergraduate students, graduate students, and faculty. In addition, the lead PI has helped to organize and attended 7th-10th Annual Faculty Women of Color in the Academy National Conference. We have also collaborated with Virginia State University (HBCU) on minority student outreach and material characterization.

 

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2021
Modified by: Kathy Lu

Overview:

In contrast to traditional nanoimprint lithography, which uses polymer materials only, a new class of hybrid materials with intricate architectures and novel functionalities have been made. The hybrid patterns offere a wide range of feature arrangements for direct device uses. This holds great scientific and application potentials by combining the knowledge at the boundaries of the particle-solvent-polymer and liquid-solid domains.
